div.p: So far we've just been using variables to store and retrieve Integers, but programs need to manipulate many other kinds of data as well (such as the text we've been sending to the console). This exercise introduces the String data type.

Languages like Java and C++ use strong typing, meaning that the type of each variable must be declared before any value can be stored in it (though both can typically be accomplished in the same statement). Such languages require that any value assigned to a variable must match that variable's type. This can help catch common programming errors even before the program starts running.

In contrast, Python chooses to maximize the freedom of the programmer, a philosophy referred to as duck typing. As long as the variables in a program behave as the code expects them to, that code need not worry about the type of data in those variables. "If it walks like a duck, and it quacks like a duck, then we might as well treat it like a duck." Fans of strong typing would instead refer to Python's approach as "weak typing".
First, read the program over and think about it.

Next (before making any changes), just click the Save and Submit button to see the type information displayed in the console, to check your prediction for the length of the original value of salutation, and to study the TypeError output. Note that the console is scrollable.
Finally, change the second assignment to the variable salutation so that last print statement in the program will display the number "11" in the console. Don't change any other lines in the program.
Come up with a String that will have the desired length and use that instead of the Integer on line 37.
